newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West Coast crudes up with WTI, trade thin.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West Coast crudes up with WTI, trade thin.

text.p: Late prices for U.S. West Coast light crudes gained ground alongside spot West Texas Intermediate (WTI) grade, but players in the Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude market remained far apart.
Deltas continued to stagnate for ANS (ANS) crude as market participants withdrew to evaluate supply needs for December.
Buyers kept bids around $2.50 under December WTI prices, while sellers were heard to offer $2.10 under.
Discounts for ANS stayed $2.30 a barrel under December WTI, with outright prices $21.95/22.25 a barrel, up 25 cents from Tuesday.

Traders said Celeron Trading and Transportation was the highest bidder in the U.S. government's offering of 15,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude from the Elk Hills Naval Petroleum Reserve in California today.
The company bid $22.078 a barrel for 4,165 bpd of crude from the 18G zone in Bakersfield, Calif. The prices was based on a WTI index.
Wilmington crude held at $18.90/19.00 a barrel.
Kern River heavy crude also held at $17.40/17.60 a barrel. --David Brinkerhoff, Los Angeles energy +1 213 380 2014
